abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Broad Based Access to
            Finance Project for Nicaragua were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: this operation
            highlights that in a highly changing institutional
            environment, such as Nicaragua, it takes time and patience
            to make an impact. It is important to ensure that Bank
            project teams and their country counterparts understand well
            project implications in terms of expected output and
            outcomes. In addition, Bank teams should timely restructure
            monitoring indicators to reflect the evolving realities on
            the ground. Project monitoring should be an integral
            component of supervision and Implementation Status and
            Results, or ISRs, with key performance indicators helping
            guide execution and decisions. Strong ownership of this
            Technical Assistance Lending, or TAL helped to make sizable
            progress following decisive policy actions by the Government
            and the National Assembly or when Micro-finance institution
            or MFIs saw clear advantages in their modernization and
            transformation. Commitment on the part of Superintendence of
            Banks and Other Financial Institutions, or SIBOIF is also
            worth noting, in contrast with the deficiencies at the
            Borrower's second-tier investment financial company, or
            FNI. The fact that Bank projects in Nicaragua, as those of
            other international organizations, need to be cleared at the
            National Assembly implies that there has to be a broad
            political consensus that includes also the implementation
            details of any initiative.
